pullRequest.body:
This PR adds some additional results about quadratic maps on modules possessing a basis

- `QuadraticMap.basis_expansion` - the expansion of a quadratic map on a free module with respect to a given basis.
- `toBilin_symm_eq_Polar` - the symmetrization of `Q.toBilin` for a quadratic map `Q` is the polar of `Q`.
- `toBilin_toQuadraticMap` - a partial complement to `toQuadraticMap_toBilin`

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

maintainer delegate

Maybe
```suggestion
    Q x = (bm.repr x).sum fun i r => (r * r) â€¢ Q (bm i) +
```
Done.
Can we add a `QuadraticMap.map_finsupp_sum` lemma and use it here?
Done, thanks @eric-wieser . That works very nicely.
I'd be inclined to introduce a `Finsupp.sym2OffDiag` here, so that this theorem holds without `LinearOrder Î¹`
Would that be something of the form `def Finsupp.sym2OffDiag (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) : Finset (Î¹ Ã— Î¹) := sorry`?

Perhaps
```
noncomputable instance : DecidablePred fun (s : Sym2 Î¹) â†¦ Â¬s.IsDiag := Classical.decPred _

noncomputable def Finsupp.sym2OffDiag (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) : Finset (Sym2 Î¹) := 
  f.support.sym2.filter (fun ij => Â¬ ij.IsDiag) 
```

?

Then the statement would be:
```
noncomputable instance : DecidableEq Î¹ := by exact Classical.typeDecidableEq Î¹

open Finsupp in
theorem map_finsupp_sum (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) (g : Î¹ â†’ R â†’ M) :
    Q (f.sum g) = (f.sum fun i r => Q (g i r)) +
    âˆ‘ ij âˆˆ f.sym2OffDiag,
    (Sym2.lift âŸ¨fun i j => (polar Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), fun _ _ => polar_comm _ _ _âŸ©) ij := by
  rw [sum, QuadraticMap.map_sum]
  apply congrArg (HAdd.hAdd _)
  sorry
```

These things both look the same to me... but not to mathlib:
```
âŠ¢ âˆ‘ ij âˆˆ Finset.filter (fun ij â†¦ Â¬ij.IsDiag) f.support.sym2,
    Sym2.lift âŸ¨fun i j â†¦ polar (â‡‘Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), â‹¯âŸ© ij =
  âˆ‘ ij âˆˆ Finset.filter (fun ij â†¦ Â¬ij.IsDiag) f.support.sym2,
    Sym2.lift âŸ¨fun i j â†¦ polar (â‡‘Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), â‹¯âŸ© ij
```
I strongly recommend not shooting yourself in the foot with `noncomputable instance : DecidableEq Î¹ := by exact Classical.typeDecidableEq Î¹`

> Would that be something of the form `def Finsupp.sym2OffDiag (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) : Finset (Î¹ Ã— Î¹) := sorry?`

No, I think I'm actually suggesting something more like
```
/-- All the products of pairs of elements in `f`. -/
noncomputable def Finsupp.sym2Mul [CommMonoidWithZero R] (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) : Sym2 Î¹ â†’â‚€ R :=
  .onFinset
    f.support.sym2
    (Sym2.lift âŸ¨fun i j => f i * f j, fun _ _ => mul_comm _ _âŸ©)
    (Sym2.ind <| by aesop)
```

@eric-wieser presumably I want to sum over something like:
```
f.sym2Mul.support.filter (fun t => Â¬ t.IsDiag)
```
But this gives me:
```
failed to synthesize
  DecidablePred fun t â†¦ Â¬t.IsDiag
```
Presumably
```
noncomputable instance : DecidablePred fun (t : Sym2 Î¹) â†¦ Â¬t.IsDiag := Classical.decPred _
```
isn't the correct solution?
I guess I need `[DecidableEq Î¹]`?

Okay, how about:
```
variable {Î¹ R M N}

variable [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup M] [AddCommGroup N] [Module R M] [Module R N] [DecidableEq Î¹]

open Finsupp in
theorem map_finsupp_sum (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) (g : Î¹ â†’ R â†’ M) :
    Q (f.sum g) = (f.sum fun i r => Q (g i r)) +
    âˆ‘ p âˆˆ f.support.sym2 with Â¬ p.IsDiag,
      Sym2.lift
        âŸ¨fun i j => (polar Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), fun i j => by simp only [polar_comm]âŸ© p := by
  rw [sum, QuadraticMap.map_sum]
  exact congrArg (HAdd.hAdd _) rfl
```

```suggestion
theorem map_finsuppSum (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (f : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) (g : Î¹ â†’ R â†’ M) :
```
to match the naming convention

The linear version of this result is `map_finsupp_sum` https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/6ac68693d219f89dcb242e9565245f1fbe108953/Mathlib/Algebra/BigOperators/Finsupp.lean#L198 @eric-wieser points out that the names should match the linear equivalents.

Similarly,
```suggestion
theorem map_finsuppLinearCombination (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) {g : Î¹ â†’ M} (l : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) :
```
or
```suggestion
theorem map_linearCombination (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) {g : Î¹ â†’ M} (l : Î¹ â†’â‚€ R) :
```

```suggestion
        âŸ¨fun i j => bm.repr x i â€¢ bm.repr x j â€¢ polar Q (bm i) (bm j), fun i j => by
```

```suggestion
lemma toBilin_symm_eq_polarBilin (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (bm : Basis Î¹ R M) :
    Q.toBilin bm + (Q.toBilin bm).flip = polarBilin Q := by
```
and is `_symm` a name for `something + something.flip`?
I was thinking of it as being symmetrised (c.f. `LinearMap.IsSymm` in the case of forms).

```suggestion
    Q (f.sum g) = f.sum (fun i r => Q (g i r)) +
```

```suggestion
      âˆ‘ p âˆˆ s.offDiag with p.1 < p.2,
```

```suggestion
        bm.repr x p.1 â€¢ bm.repr y p.2 â€¢ (B + B.flip) (bm p.1) (bm p.2) := by
```

```suggestion
        âŸ¨fun i j => l i â€¢ l j â€¢ polar Q (g i) (g j), fun i j => by
```

```suggestion
        rw [toQuadraticMap_toBilin Q]
```
same thing below twice
The rest of this PR compiles fine without these theorems, which seem to be a real mouthful. Are you sure we need them?
They don't belong in this PR, so I've split them out into a separate PR #21138. Not sure yet if they're actually useful. Possibly more a case of me thinking aloud.
Looks like you kept exactly the lemmas Kevin was suggesting you get rid of ðŸ˜†

To my mind the lemmas left in this PR are the useful ones (e.g. if two quadratic maps agree on the basis and their polars evaluated at pairs of basis elements agree then they must be equal) and the other PR has the less useful lemmas.

```suggestion
        bm.repr x i â€¢ bm.repr y i â€¢ B (bm i) (bm i) +
```

```suggestion
```
These don't seem to be needed.

```suggestion
        âŸ¨fun i j => polar Q (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), fun i j => by simp only [polar_comm]âŸ© p := by
```

```suggestion
    Q x = (bm.repr x).sum (fun i r => (r * r) â€¢ Q (bm i)) +
```
Do we have this theorem for `LinearMap`? I would expect we do, and if so we should try to make the naming match.
The bilinear map version is `LinearMap.sum_repr_mul_repr_mul` and the bilinear form version is `LinearMap.BilinForm.sum_repr_mul_repr_mul`
So something like `QuadraticMap.sum_repl_sq_add_sum_repl_mul_polar` with the `Q x` on the RHS?
The linear equivalent is `Finsupp.apply_linearCombination`.
